case_title: AURANGZEB, SUBDIVISIONAL EDUCATION OFFICER, SWABI vs ISTIKHAR ALI

accussed_details.name: Istikhar Ali
allegation: Drawing salary from Education Department while undergoing legal apprenticeship

complaint_summary: Aurangzeb alleged that Istikhar Ali, a P.T.C. Teacher, engaged in professional misconduct by drawing a government salary while undergoing legal apprenticeship and practicing law without proper enrollment as an Advocate.
investigation_summary: The Disciplinary Committee of the N.-W.F.P. Bar Council initiated proceedings. Evidence was recorded, including statements from witnesses and submission of documents. The respondent denied allegations, claiming he was not enrolled as an Advocate and had obtained proper permissions for his education.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal concluded that it lacked jurisdiction as the respondent was not enrolled as an Advocate under the N.-W.F.P. Bar Council. The complaint was returned to the complainant for presentation before the appropriate forum.
tribunal_findings: Respondent was not enrolled as an Advocate on the roll of N.-W.F.P. Bar Council, thus the Tribunal lacked jurisdiction. Complaint returned to complainant for presentation before the proper forum.
Decision_or_verdict: Complaint returned to the complainant for presentation before the proper forum.

decision.jurisdiction: Tribunal lacks jurisdiction as respondent is not enrolled as an Advocate.
decision.action: Complaint returned to complainant for presentation before the proper forum.

legal_arguments: Prosecution argued that the respondent violated the Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973, by practicing law while in government service without prior permission.
Defense argued that the respondent obtained proper permissions for his education and did not commit professional misconduct.
statutes: Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973
Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Rules, 1976
sections: Section 41 of the Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973

legal_references.primary_statute: Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973
legal_references.rules_referenced: Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Rules, 1976
legal_references.jurisdiction_section: Section 41 of the Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973

witnesses: Abdul Jabar Khan (Secretary, N.W.-F.P. Bar Council)

witness_statement.Abdul Jabar Khan: Produced two intimation forms submitted by the respondent, confirming he was not enrolled as an Advocate.
witness_statement.Habibullah: Confirmed the respondent's termination from government service and his failure to apply for enrollment as an Advocate.

key_issues: Whether the respondent committed professional misconduct by practicing law while in government service.
Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction to entertain the complaint.

legal_terms.Professional Misconduct: Violation of ethical or legal standards by a professional.
legal_terms.Jurisdiction: The authority of a court or tribunal to hear a case.

words_and_phrases.Professional Misconduct: Conduct that violates the ethical or legal standards of a profession.
words_and_phrases.Jurisdiction: The legal authority to hear and decide a case.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of professional misconduct against a government teacher practicing law without proper enrollment. The Tribunal ruled it lacked jurisdiction and returned the complaint for filing in the appropriate forum.
